UMC opens drive-thru coronavirus screening site
There is now one drive-up coronavirus screening site in Lubbock.UMC Health System opened a screening center just south of its main facility at 602 Indiana

form.name: siteSearchForm

div.h1: UMC opens drive-thru coronavirus screening site

div.p: There is now one drive-up coronavirus screening site in Lubbock.

br.p: UMC Health System opened a screening center just south of its main facility at 602 Indiana Ave., right in front of the Texas Tech softball fields. Signs along the road direct traffic.
Healthcare officials are still asking individuals to call a primary care physician before going to any facility.
Not everyone who comes to the drive-thrus will be tested, emphasized officials from both UMC and Covenant Health at a news conference Thursday afternoon.

Individuals are asked to bring health insurance information if they have it. There is no upfront cost for a COVID-19 test, though patients could be billed later by the Austin lab providing and processing the tests.
Anyone who meets the testing criteria but is concerned about potential costs is urged to contact the City of Lubbock’s Health Department.

Dr. Mike Ragain, UMC vice president and chief medical officer, said people will first be screened to see if they meet current testing requirements. People will be asked about their symptoms and recent travel history. Ragain said these testing requirements are changing regularly.
Before doing a COVID-19 test, healthcare workers are also testing for flu and strep throat, which can have similar respiratory and high fever symptoms.

Eric Finley, public information officer for UMC, said within a few hours of opening its drive-thru clinic, the hospital had tested one person for COVID-19, and multiple people for other viruses. Results will not be available for 24 to 72 hours, depending on the processing center’s capacity.

At 2:30 p.m. Thursday, there were about 15 cars in the drive-thru testing line at UMC. Inside the vehicles, some people wore masks. Many cars only had a driver, but some had at least two people in the car.
Ray Peznowski was one of the people in line. Peznowski had no symptoms, but had traveled in Pennsylvania and through Denver’s airport in the past week.
He took the precautions he could while traveling and is practicing social distancing and frequent hand washing. He said he was trying to get tested to protect himself and his family.
“I’m not that guy that worries about things much, but I am taking precautionary measures,” he said.
Ragain said available testing resources will go toward people who are deemed to be at the highest risk.

Federal guidelines restrict authorities from revealing how many COVID-19 tests have been taken. Ragain said UMC had six patient tests pending as of Thursday morning, not including the one conducted after the drive-thru screening process.

Dr. Craig Rhyne, Covenant Health regional chief medical officer, said his system received “multiple” negative test results, but that the number of positive cases was the only firm data point to share about testing.

At least 2,335 COVID-19 tests had been administered in Texas as of Thursday, according to an afternoon update from the Texas Department of State Health Services and the Center for Disease Controls. More than 425 people had been tested since Wednesday’s update.

As of Thursday evening, there are three confirmed cases of COVID-19 discovered in Lubbock. One patient is a 15-25 year old Texas Tech student, another is someone over age 60 from Hockley County and the third is a Lubbock man between 40 and 50 whose case investigation is ongoing. All confirmed cases are travel related.
There are more than 160 confirmed cases of coronavirus in Texas. Three people have died from the disease in the state.
Everyone is encouraged to practice social distancing, stay home if possible and wash hands frequently.
